xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: This study is financially supported by the The Thailand Research Fund (TRF-RSA5780055) and National Nanotechnology Center (NANOTEC), NSTDA, Ministry of Science and Technology, Thailand, through its program of the Center of Excellence Network. This work is also partially supported by a Grant for International Research Integration: Chula Research Scholar and E. R. was supported by a Postdoctoral Fellowship (Ratchadaphiseksomphot Endowment Fund).

organization.$: Nanotec-CU Center of Excellence on Food and Agriculture

head.citation-title: An Atom-Economic Approach for Vinylation of Indoles and Phenols Using Calcium Carbide as Acetylene Surrogate
head.abstracts: © 2016 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, WeinheimAn efficient N-vinylation of indoles and O-vinylation of phenols to give N-vinyl indoles and phenyl vinyl ethers is reported. The vinylated products can be produced in satisfactory to excellent yields (65–92 %) upon treatment of indoles or phenols with calcium carbide in wet solvents in a standard laboratory setup. Key features of this reaction include the use of calcium carbide as a safe and inexpensive slow released acetylene source for N- and O-vinylation under simple reaction conditions without the need for metal catalyst or halogenated substrates.

organization.$: Nanotec-CU Center of Excellence on Food and Agriculture

grant-text.$: This study is financially supported by the The Thailand Research Fund (TRF-RSA5780055) and National Nanotechnology Center (NANOTEC), NSTDA, Ministry of Science and Technology, Thailand, through its program of the Center of Excellence Network. This work is also partially supported by a Grant for International Research Integration: Chula Research Scholar and E. R. was supported by a Postdoctoral Fellowship (Ratchadaphiseksomphot Endowment Fund).

coredata.dc:description: An efficient N-vinylation of indoles and O-vinylation of phenols to give N-vinyl indoles and phenyl vinyl ethers is reported. The vinylated products can be produced in satisfactory to excellent yields (65–92 %) upon treatment of indoles or phenols with calcium carbide in wet solvents in a standard laboratory setup. Key features of this reaction include the use of calcium carbide as a safe and inexpensive slow released acetylene source for N- and O-vinylation under simple reaction conditions without the need for metal catalyst or halogenated substrates.
coredata.dc:title: An Atom-Economic Approach for Vinylation of Indoles and Phenols Using Calcium Carbide as Acetylene Surrogate
